title.value: Deep Multi-Representation Learning for Data Clustering
title.justification: The title is directly mentioned at the beginning and throughout the paper.
title.quote: Deep Multi-Representation Learning for Data Clustering

extractions.description: This paper proposes a deep multi-representation learning (DML) framework for data clustering, where difficult-to-cluster data groups are associated with their own optimized latent spaces. Autoencoders are used to generate both cluster-specific and general latent spaces, and a novel loss function combining weighted reconstruction and clustering losses is introduced. The method outperforms state-of-the-art clustering approaches, especially on imbalanced datasets.

type.justification: The paper tests the proposed DML framework on several benchmark datasets and compares its performance with other clustering methods.
type.quote: Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed DML framework and loss function outperform state-of-the-art clustering approaches.

name.justification: The paper focuses on the application of deep learning techniques for improving data clustering performance.
name.quote: Deep clustering incorporates embedding into clustering in order to find a lower-dimensional space suitable for clustering task.

name.justification: The paper uses autoencoders to generate cluster-specific and general latent spaces for data clustering.
name.quote: Autoencoders are employed for generating the cluster-specific and general latent spaces.

name.justification: The paper proposes a novel loss function combining weighted reconstruction and clustering losses.
name.quote: To specialize each autoencoder in its associated data cluster(s), we propose a novel and effective loss function which consists of weighted reconstruction and clustering losses of the data points.

name.justification: The general autoencoder is used to generate latent spaces for easy clusters in the DML framework.
name.quote: DML trains a common autoencoder, called General AE, for the easy clusters and cluster-specific autoencoders for the difficult ones.

is_contributed.justification: The general autoencoder is an integral part of the proposed DML framework.
is_contributed.quote: To summarize, the main contributions of this work are: We propose the novel concept of deep multi-representation learning which performs the data clustering task by employing multiple autoencoders: a general autoencoder for the easy clusters and cluster-specific autoencoders for the difficult ones.

is_executed.justification: The general autoencoder is trained as part of the proposed method.
is_executed.quote: For each dataset’s best result is shown in bold. The second-top results are denoted by an asterisk (*).

is_compared.justification: The paper compares the performance of the proposed method, including the general autoencoder, with various other clustering methods.
is_compared.quote: Effectiveness of DML in boosting performance of the state-of-the-art AE-based clustering methods is shown in Table I.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The general autoencoder is a part of the proposed DML framework and does not have a separate reference paper.

name.justification: Cluster-specific autoencoders are used to generate distinct, optimized latent spaces for difficult-to-cluster groups in the DML framework.
name.quote: DML trains a common autoencoder, called General AE, for the easy clusters and cluster-specific autoencoders for the difficult ones.

is_contributed.justification: The cluster-specific autoencoder is an integral part of the proposed DML framework.
is_contributed.quote: To summarize, the main contributions of this work are: We propose the novel concept of deep multi-representation learning which performs the data clustering task by employing multiple autoencoders: a general autoencoder for the easy clusters and cluster-specific autoencoders for the difficult ones.

is_executed.justification: Cluster-specific autoencoders are trained as part of the proposed method.
is_executed.quote: For each dataset’s best result is shown in bold. The second-top results are denoted by an asterisk (*).

is_compared.justification: The paper compares the performance of the proposed method, including the cluster-specific autoencoders, with various other clustering methods.
is_compared.quote: Effectiveness of DML in boosting performance of the state-of-the-art AE-based clustering methods is shown in Table I.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The cluster-specific autoencoder is a part of the proposed DML framework and does not have a separate reference paper.

name.justification: MNIST is used to evaluate the clustering performance of the proposed DML framework.
name.quote: Effectiveness of our proposed DML framework is evaluated on six commonly used datasets. The datasets are: (1) MNIST comprises of 60,000 training and 10,000 test gray-scale handwritten digits with size 28 × 28.

referenced_paper_title.value: Yann LeCun et al. “Gradient-based learning applied to document recognition.” Proceedings of the IEEE, 1998.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper provides documentation for the MNIST dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Yann LeCun et al. “Gradient-based learning applied to document recognition.” Proceedings of the IEEE, 1998.

name.justification: Fashion MNIST is used to evaluate the clustering performance of the proposed DML framework.
name.quote: (2) Fashion MNIST contains various types of fashion items. The number of samples and image size are as same as those of the MNIST dataset.

referenced_paper_title.value: Han Xiao, Kashif Rasul, and Roland Vollgraf. “Fashion-mnist: a novel image dataset for benchmarking machine learning algorithms.” arXiv preprint arXiv:1708.07747, 2017.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper provides documentation for the Fashion MNIST dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Han Xiao, Kashif Rasul, and Roland Vollgraf. “Fashion-mnist: a novel image dataset for benchmarking machine learning algorithms.” arXiv preprint arXiv:1708.07747, 2017.

name.justification: 2MNIST, created by concatenating MNIST and Fashion MNIST, is used to evaluate the clustering performance of the proposed DML framework.
name.quote: (3) 2MNIST is a more challenging dataset which is created by concatenation of the two MNIST and Fashion MNIST datasets.

referenced_paper_title.justification: 2MNIST is a synthesized combination of MNIST and Fashion MNIST and does not have a separate reference paper.

name.justification: CIFAR-10 is used to evaluate the clustering performance of the proposed DML framework.
name.quote: (4) CIFAR-10 contains of 60,000 RGB images from 10 different categories, where the size of each image is 32 × 32.

referenced_paper_title.value: Alex Krizhevsky, Geoffrey Hinton, et al. "Learning multiple layers of features from tiny images." University of Toronto, 2009.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper provides documentation for the CIFAR-10 dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Alex Krizhevsky, Geoffrey Hinton, et al. "Learning multiple layers of features from tiny images." University of Toronto, 2009.

name.justification: STL-10 is used to evaluate the clustering performance of the proposed DML framework.
name.quote: (5) STL-10 comprises of 13,000 96 × 96 RGB images from different objects.

referenced_paper_title.value: Adam Coates, Andrew Ng, and Honglak Lee. "An analysis of single-layer networks in unsupervised feature learning." Proceedings of the Fourteenth International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Statistics, 2011.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper provides documentation for the STL-10 dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Adam Coates, Andrew Ng, and Honglak Lee. "An analysis of single-layer networks in unsupervised feature learning." Proceedings of the Fourteenth International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Statistics, 2011.

name.justification: CIFAR-100 is used to evaluate the clustering performance of the proposed DML framework.
name.quote: (6) CIFAR-100 is similar to the CIFAR-10 in terms of number of samples and image size. However, it has 20 super groups based on the similarity between images.

referenced_paper_title.value: Alex Krizhevsky, Geoffrey Hinton, et al. "Learning multiple layers of features from tiny images." University of Toronto, 2009.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper provides documentation for the CIFAR-100 dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Alex Krizhevsky, Geoffrey Hinton, et al. "Learning multiple layers of features from tiny images." University of Toronto, 2009.
